Seating Arrangements (Linear, Circular).question: There are five men named A, B, C, D, and E facing south and five ladies named M, N, O, P, and Q facing north in a line parallel to the first line. Q is situated across from B and to the left of D. C and N are positioned on opposite sides of the diagonal. E is directly facing O, who is to the right of M. P, on the left of Q, is on the opposite side of D. M is positioned at one end of the line. If O and P, A and E, and B and Q exchange positions, who will be the second person to the right of the person opposite to the second person to the right of P?
Seating Arrangements (Linear, Circular).explanation: The arrangement is Men (South): C-E-D-B-A and Ladies (North): M-O-P-Q-N. After swapping O-P, A-E, and B-Q, the Men become C-A-D-Q-E and Ladies M-P-O-B-N. P is at position 2. Second to P's right is B (pos 4). Opposite B is Q. Facing South, Q's second right is A.

Seating Arrangements (Linear, Circular).question: There are five men named A, B, C, D, and E facing south and five ladies named M, N, O, P, and Q facing north in a line parallel to the first line. Q is situated across from B and to the left of D. C and N are positioned on opposite sides of the diagonal. E is directly facing O, who is to the right of M. P, on the left of Q, is on the opposite side of D. M is positioned at one end of the line. If B substitutes for E, E replaces Q, and Q takes the spot of B, who will be situated second to the left of the individual opposite O?
Seating Arrangements (Linear, Circular).explanation: Original arrangement: Men C-E-D-B-A; Ladies M-O-P-Q-N. After the cycle (B replaces E, E replaces Q, Q replaces B), the Men's row becomes C-B-D-Q-A. The person opposite O is B (facing South). The second position to B's left (viewer's right) is Q.

Family tree logic.question: Arjun says, “She is the wife of my mother’s son.” How is the woman related to Arjun?
Family tree logic.explanation: My mother's son could be Arjun or his brother. Since 'Wife' is not among the choices, we assume it refers to his brother. The wife of Arjun's brother is his Sister-in-law.

Family tree logic.question: Sita said, “The man in the picture is my husband’s father’s only son.” How is the man related to Sita?
Family tree logic.explanation: Sita's 'husband's father' is her father-in-law. The 'only son' of her father-in-law is Sita's husband himself. Therefore, the man in the picture is her Husband.

Family tree logic.question: Neha points to a girl and says, “She is the only daughter of my father’s father.” How is the girl related to Neha?
Family tree logic.explanation: My father's father refers to Neha's grandfather. The only daughter of the grandfather is the sister of Neha's father. The father's sister is related to Neha as her Aunt.

Mixed Series (Alphanumeric).question: JAK, KBL, LCM, MDN, _____
Mixed Series (Alphanumeric).explanation: Middle letters follow alphabetical order A, B, C, D, E. First and third letters increase alphabetically, and the third letter becomes the first letter of the next term. Hence NEO.

Mixed Series (Alphanumeric).question: BCB, DED, FGF, HIH, ___
Mixed Series (Alphanumeric).explanation: First two letters progress alphabetically in pairs: B,C → D,E → F,G → H,I → J,K. The third letter repeats the first letter of each term. Hence JKJ.

Mixed Series (Alphanumeric).question: ZA_5, Y_4B, XC_6, W_3D, _____
Mixed Series (Alphanumeric).explanation: There are three series to look for here. The first letters are alphabetical in reverse: Z, Y, X, W, V. The second letters are in alphabetical order, beginning with A. The number series is as follows: 5, 4, 6, 3, 7. Hence VE_7.

Syllogisms.question:
Statement I: Some plums are peaches
Statement II: All peaches are apples
Statement III: Some apples are mangoes
Conclusion I: Some mangoes are peaches
Conclusion II: Some apples are peaches
choices: A) If only conclusion I follow
B) If only conclusion II follows
C) If conclusion I and II both follow
D) If neither conclusion I nor conclusion II follows
Syllogisms.explanation: All peaches are apples ensures some apples are peaches. No definite link proves mangoes are peaches.

Syllogisms.question:
Statement I: All trees are shrubs
Statement II: No shrub is a sapling
Statement III: All saplings are grass
Conclusions I: No tree is a grass
Conclusion II: Some saplings being trees is a possibility
choices: A) If only conclusion I follow
B) If only conclusion II follows
C) If conclusion I and II both follow
D) If neither conclusion I nor conclusion II follows
Syllogisms.explanation: No direct tree–grass relation is definite. Trees cannot be saplings, so II is not possible.

Syllogisms.question:
Statement I: Some green is red
Statement II: Some red is blue
Statement III: All blue is yellow
Conclusion I: Some yellow is green
Conclusion II: Some yellow is red
choices: A) If only conclusion I follow
B) If only conclusion II follows
C) If conclusion I and II both follow
D) If neither conclusion I nor conclusion II follows
Syllogisms.explanation: Red overlaps blue and blue ⊆ yellow, so some yellow is red. Green link is not definite.
